abstract: Representative Paul Ryan’s splashy new deficit-reduction proposal is just one of many introduced in the last few years. Will this one get traction when the others haven’t?
snippet: Representative Paul Ryan’s splashy new deficit-reduction proposal is just one of many introduced in the last few years. Will this one get traction when the others haven’t?
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan,  Republican from Wisconsin, released a dramatic new deficit-reduction proposal Tuesday, one that would slash $5.8 trillion from spending levels over the next decade. Among the more controversial highlights is a cap on Medicare and Medicaid spending, by giving individual Medicare recipients vouchers of a certain amount, and block grants to states for Medicaid. The pundit consensus seems to be that Mr. Ryan’s plan will be the framework for thinking about how to resolve budget issues — in David Brooks’s words, “the standard of seriousness for anybody who wants to play in this discussion.”

headline.main: The Problem With Deficit Solutions Like Representative Ryan’s

abstract: Treasury officials discussed new financial regulations with dozens of finance industry executives and lobbyists from banks, asset management firms and trade groups in February, government records show.
snippet: Treasury officials discussed new financial regulations with dozens of finance industry executives and lobbyists from banks, asset management firms and trade groups in February, government records show.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has plenty to say about the Dodd-Frank Act, and the Treasury Department is listening.

headline.main: Wall Street Lobbies Treasury on Dodd-Frank

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
